awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2021 ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing  (ACM/IEEE SEC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal is to seek travel support for up to 20 students to attend the ACM/IEEE SEC in San Jose CA from Dec. 14-17, 2021. This leading technical conference is the primary venue for presenting new research results in the area of "edge computing", a new paradigm in which the resources of a small data center are placed at the edge of the Internet, in close proximity to mobile devices, sensors, and end users, and the emerging Internet of Things. The conference will consist of technical paper presentations, panels, PhD forums, posters, and demonstrations. It will also feature keynote speeches from leading researchers and practitioners in the field.

Participation in SEC 2021 and similar conferences are valuable and important activities of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposes students to leading work and practical industry practices in this important area of research. This may have an important impact on career development. The goal of the funds is to support approximately 20 student participants at recognized US institutions of higher education. Funds will be dispersed with preference given to students who would not otherwise be able to attend the conference and students who are not already scheduled to present a paper, paying particular attention to diversity and relevance of the student's research interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to support travels of US-based students to attend the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (SEC), which took place in San Jose, CA, December 14-17, 2021.

We received 21 applications for the travel grant from students in US institutions and 3 applications from International institutions. In the end we awarded 20 students to receive the grant, with each student to receive up to $1080 for the award. After the conference, we received a total of $16,387.61 for reimbursement payments.

We was also able to support another 5 applicants by the conference sponsorship.

Among the 24 grant recipients,

- all were enrolled in a CISE (Computer and Information Science and Engineering) related Ph.D. program at the time when the conference took place;

- 5 students (21% of all the recipients) are from under-represented groups;

- 14 students (58%) first attended the SEC conference due to this travel grant support;

- 19 students (80%) students had a first-authored paper to present at the conference; and

- 3 students (12.5%) participated the Ph.D. forum of the conference.

All the supported students attended the conference and the poster/demo session.

The following students were awarded this grant:

- Sidi Lu, Wayne State University

- Hazem Abdelhafez, University of British Columbia

- Yitao Chen, Arizona State University

- Kaiqi Zhao, Arizona State University

- Babak Badnava, University of Kansas

- Young Dae Kwon, University of Cambridge

- James Choncholas, Georgia Tech

- Pinyarash Pinyoanuntapong, University of North Carolina Charlotte

- Kumseok Jung, University of British Columbia

- Liangkai Liu, Wayne State University

- Nabeel Nasir, University of Virginia

- Jinghui Liao, Wayne State University

- Marina Neseem, Brown University

- Yujie Hui, Ohio State University

- Harshit Gupta, Georgia Tech

- Pavana Prakash, University of Houston

- Sibendu Paul, Purdue University

- Yiyue Chen, University of Texas at Austin

- Eugene Kuznetsov, Arizona State University


Last Modified: 07/13/2023
Modified by: An Wang
